comments.commentBody:
Karzai is called a leader by the US. To Afghans, he's an American puppet.

Is that what you meant by referring to him as a "so called leader"?

As a Democrat, a liberal, and an already wavering supporter of President Obama, I am shocked and outraged that an apology would even be considered. Quite the contrary. This highlights the low grade posturing by a third rate, so called leader, Karzai.

My thinning belief in Obama will disappear completely if he acquiesces.
Anyone care to guess how much Oregon (Phil Knight) spends on uniforms each year?  On the other hand, he also funds other departments at the university.

"Sports teams once had simple fashion rules. Wear one uniform at home, usually white, and another on the road"

At least in Football, the tradition has always been to wear the dark uniform at home--exactly the opposite of what the writer says in his start to the article (except perhaps for the Dallas Cowboys and Washington Redskins). Additionally, the White-NonWhite Uniform combination (along with stripes for officials) really only came about once TV took off. Before that, teams would wear colored uniforms, and might have an away uniform if the other team had same colored jersey. When TV came around (black and white TV), it was difficult to tell the teams apart, so the white away jersey was born, along with stripes for the officials (who previously wore white shirts).
Where will it end? A new uniform for every game? Every half? Every quarter?
As a well-know sage noted, no one ever went broke underestimating the taste of the American people [and that goes double for Big Time Sports Inc.]

Your on the right track.....when and where did Congress abide by the U.S. Constitution Article I, Section 8 and declare war on Afghanistan providing the rationale to protect our national security interest, clear objectives, a draft and shared sacrifice and definition of "victory"?   Vietnams will continue to repeat themselves until we amend the Constitution and force Congress FIRST to march into war, then you will NEVER, EVER see another Vietnam, Iraq or Afghanistan debacle.

I certainly don't blame a lower income parent for opting for the Pop-Tarts, which were buy-one-get-one free at the supermarket that week. For less than $7, she was able to provide snack for the whole class.....It's all very complicated. We need nutrition science, sociology to understand the dynamics of the poor and psychology to figure out how to put things together. The healthier food is more expensive, particularlly the pre-sliced apples. One thing the health care system does in Mexico is prevention.
Thanks
http://www.dietkart.com/

This is a civil war among competing tribes/assorted interests, the "government" forces simply one of the competing parties. The US is supporting one of many contenders. This is no longer the fight of the US (if it ever was in the sense of making war on the Taliban, an indigenous force), certainly after Tora Bora & delivery of "payback" by the overthrow in 2001 of the regime which harbored Al-Qaeda.

I don't think attracting wealthy applicants is the goal behind Northwestern wearing those ugly uniforms. If it wanted to, NW could fill its freshman class with children of one per-centers

Under Armour, the company that makes the uniforms, has a partnership with Wounded Warrior. This venture raises awareness and the proceeds from it go, in large part, to help the brave men and women who have been damaged in war, both physically and emotionally.

I know leaders at both NW and UA and I can assure you that your cynical, simplistic way of looking at this issue is incorrect.

I'm not sure what Northwestern was thinking with those horrible uniforms, other than that maybe a display of crass jingoism on national TV might bring in a few more wealthy applicants from Republican districts.

Sigh.... Does anyone else miss the days when having an active ROTC was enough to damage any serious university's credibility? I'm totally behind our veterans--I just don't think much of the flag-waving that made them veterans in the first place.

For the academics at that respected university that, I offer "De gustibus non est disputandum."
For their athletics program, a translation has to suffice "There is no disputing of tastes."
But my taste is identical to that of Bob Az.

The uniforms that Northwestern wore against Michigan were b-u-double-t ugly and did no service to the players or the supposed honorees.  But I guess any distraction is worth grasping at in the midst of the current losing streak.
So you've done these things, Nora?  Is that how you know?
If folks wouldn't buy all that garbage, they'd go back to two unis per team.
totally agree. they look like old chain gang uniforms. prison is no joke for the nfl these days.
Since you bring up PANDA, MTF, our cub is now over 10 pounds and is starting to stand on her back legs for a little bit and try to walk.

YES! Pacman.

Couldn't remember which one. Just had the IMAGE from the screen of one of those big arcade console games, in the mists of memory.

Also thought it could have been a logo of a video-game company.
MTF, re PACman....Did you compare with constructor's initials?

This puzzle had a lot to love, but it was a trial for me. When I got to the unchecked squares in my first Across pass, I looked at the grid for the first time. I squinted "magic eye" style. I channeled Rorschach. I wasted precious ticking seconds on the time clock. All I came up with was a roadkill butterfly. Now that I've seen Mr HP and know what to call it, I still don't see a gas gauge in this grid. There's an arrow? Huh? Yes, I see the circles around ARROW and GAS GAUGE. Am I not supposed to look at the whole grid, but only the E - big arc - F? OK, I'll go with that.

What I loved were all of the terrific words Peter crammed in here. Everything I didn't know, I should have.

How many times has Biden voted to break a tie in the Senate as VP? Zero.

How many times did Cheney vote to break a tie in the Senate as VP? Eight, including tax cuts for the 1%.

Time for Reid to grow a pair with the rest of the Democrats and start going on the offensive.
Absolutely. Kudos to John, Ted Williams was an ace combat fighter, not just a scrub. You can excel at many things.

DL, PTAS could boost "the senior class", e.g.

HONUS Wagner was anti-tobacco, and baseball cards in his day were issued with chewing tobacco. He not only demanded that they stop printing the ones with his picture, but I think he made them stop selling the ones they had already printed. So the only ones ever available to collectors were the ones that had already been sold before they were recalled. Some of those have been lost, destroyed, or damaged, so there are very very few left.

People who have a lot of money will pay a lot of money for anything rare, whether it is an undrinkable wine once owned by Jefferson, a moon rock, or a baseball card.

The HONUS Wagner chewing-tobacco baseball card is, indeed, the costliest ever sold.
Hypocrites! Watch out. This will bite you in the butt!
With no intention of overdoing the "fivethirtyam is so knowledgeable in a seemingly-effortless manner" theme, my new phrase for the day was "fulcrum dot".

OK, I just (finally) looked at XWord Info, where Jeff has kindly made the picture a little clearer for me (thanks, Jeff).  The ARROW is making sense to me now -- the black square between ARROW and NOFEE is the fulcrum dot.  I do like these puzzles that make a picture, really I do.

Mr Greene,

I notice you don't live in Moscow, or St Petersburg. How come?

Do we need to spend more on "defense" than the rest of the world combined? No. Do we need to be "projecting force" around the Globe? No. But if you are naive enough to believe that we do not require some soldiers, sailors and marines to protect this country, you are sorely misguided and undereducated.

More precisely, at what point in the history of mankind did a population defend itself from those who would take their lives and treasures, or from those who simply believed in another god, without using force?

Those of you who insist there are "millions" of cancellation letters: now tell me how many are the direct result of the ACA, and tell me also how many there were in previous years. Cancellation is what insurance companies do.

Many of the objections Edsall refers to are legitimate and also, as a proponent of single payer, I have always thought the ACA too complex. But enough people are already benefiting, and many more will, that the problems are no excuse to sink it cold turkey. If it is sunk, expect a pro single-payer backlash.

You are so right. The Koch-funded jihad against anything that might help the peons and hurt their bottom line is relentless and we need to push back.
Nearly 50 million people were uninsured before the ACA.
Republicans were not there every time my individual health insurance premiums went up 30% each year.
I guess that wasn't something they could use for political advantage so it wasn't important.

Just a postscript - here's a link for those of you who doubt there's a deliberate campaign to undermine the ACA:

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/20/obamacare-alec-republican-l....

So now Edsall jumps on the bandwagon of doom and gloom. The negative public opinion is being driven by one of the most relentless bombardment of propaganda imaginable (not to mention the obstruction of several states run by Republicans); it's orchestrated by tons of big money and the media have taken the bait. And then there's the double-headed Koch-funded to sabotage the process, spreading bad news about the sign-up process while targeting young people to persuade them not to sign up.

The "millions" (really?) of cancellation letters are highlighted but already notable success stories from several states are totally ignored.

I agree. As a rule of thumb when the host starts shooting at you ( green on Blue incidents) it's time to leave the party. You have worn out your welcome.
Can Mr. Karzai make it any clearer? They want us OUT. The American public wants us out.
GET OUT!!!
Way past time for us to be out of Afghanistan.
How is this relevant to an article on parental involvement in the writing of personal statements?
No, he has been alerted that actions have consequences.

An alert to parents, right now we are defending our son against expulsion at a college because of zero tolerance in the dorms against pot. Un-named spies reported that he smelled like pot, when questioned by hall advisor he admitted he had smoked off campus and apologized. The result is that he is evicted from dorms, cafeteria, parking lots and sports club on campus for one year. We retained a lawyer for the Campus Judiciary phase of this. She said it's too bad he admitted, because there was no proof, just vague and contradictory circumstantial evidence. Colleges are turning into snitch factories  and my son has been taught at his first quarter of college to be a liar next time.

EEN, putting aside for a moment that you were in Harlem and didn't stop by with some Caldo Gallego, some pasteles, or at least some chorizo:

I had once told you that I thought there were buildings on Roosevelt Island, where I once lived, designed by J. SERT (or his firm). Was I close to correct? And what did you think of the rest of the architecture on Main Street?

Also, no offseason visit to CitiField? They offer tours! You can see all 3 YBNYM retired numbers!

five, In a permanent state of inebriation or sporadic sobriety?

"I love the sunshine of your smile, I love the laughter in your eyes!"
Note: Follow the ARROW to five's avatar to confirm above observation

Howie
